column3: Making research free at the point of use
column8: free at the point of use

column3: Open Access means that the reader has unrestricted, free online access to scholarly publications. It also means that there are almost no restrictions for others to further distribute or use the material. Exactly what readers are allowed to do with the work is still, however, in the hands of the author: they are free to choose either a liberal or a more restrictive Creative Commons license.
column8: reader has unrestricted, free online access
column11: It also means that there are almost no restrictions for others to further distribute or use the material. Exactly what readers are allowed to do with the work is still, however, in the hands of the author: they are free to choose either a liberal or a more restrictive Creative Commons license.
column14: almost no restrictions for others to further distribute or use the material. Exactly what readers are allowed to do with the work is still, however, in the hands of the author: they are free to choose either a liberal or a more restrictive Creative Commons license.
column18: almost no restrictions for others to further distribute or use the material. Exactly what readers are allowed to do with the work is still, however, in the hands of the author: they are free to choose either a liberal or a more restrictive Creative Commons license.

column3: By “open access” to [peer-reviewed research literature], we mean its free availability on the public internet, permitting any users to read, download, copy, distribute, print, search, or link to the full texts of these articles, crawl them for indexing, pass them as data to software, or use them for any other lawful purpose, without financial, legal, or technical barriers other than those inseparable from gaining access to the internet itself. The only constraint on reproduction and distribution, and the only role for copyright in this domain, should be to give authors control over the integrity of their work and the right to be properly acknowledged and cited.
column18: or use them for any other lawful purpose, without financial, legal, or technical barriers other than those inseparable from gaining access to the internet itself
column30: without financial, legal, or technical barriers

column3: Open Access (OA) makes scholarly research permanently available online to view without restriction. OA can also allow content to be published in a way that allows readers to redistribute, re-use and adapt the content in new works.

column11: can also allow content to be published in a way that allows readers to redistribute, re-use and adapt the content
column14: can also allow content to be published in a way that allows readers to redistribute
column17: can also allow content to be published in a way that allows readers to redistribute, re-use and adapt the content in new works

column3: Open access (OA) refers to freely available, digital, online information. Open access scholarly literature is free of charge and often carries less restrictive copyright and licensing barriers than traditionally published works, for both the users and the authors.

column3: Publishing open access makes your work immediately and permanently available online for everyone, worldwide.

Open Access (OA) means you can publish your research so it is free to access online as soon as it is published, meaning anyone can read (and cite) your work. Publishing OA also means published research can generally be re-used by third parties with few, or no, restrictions.
